column1: Consensus Assessments Initiative Questionnaire CAIQ Lite

column6: https://octopus.com/docs/security/caiq

column4: Question Text
column6: Notes

column4: Do you use an automated source code analysis tool to detect security defects in code prior to production?
column6: We use tools that detect vulnerabilities within our source code and its dependencies. These tools automatically run when new code is added to the project code base.
column7: Rubocop, CI, Github Security, CodeQL for VS Code

column4: (SaaS only) Do you review your applications for security vulnerabilities and address any issues prior to deployment to production?
column6: In addition to the tools mentioned in AIS-01.2 which will block the deployment of unsuitable code, new code is peer reviewed prior to deployment to production.

column4: Are all identified security, contractual, and regulatory requirements for customer access contractually addressed and remediated prior to granting customers access to data, assets, and information systems?
column6: Clear information is presented to users on what the entered data is for and who can access their data. For example: members know who will be able to view the information that they are asked to submit.

column4: Does your data management policies and procedures require audits to verify data input and output integrity routines?
column8: Unsure, need to find more info. See https://octopus.com/docs/security/caiq or https://www.green-triangle.com/caiq/

column4: Do you allow tenants to view your SOC2/ISO 27001 or similar third-party audit or certification reports?
column6: Our Cloud provider, AWS, has certification for compliance with ISO/IEC 27001. We follow all the best practices recommended by AWS, but we have not applied for ISO 27001/SOC2 certification ourselves at this stage.

column4: Do you conduct network penetration tests of your cloud service infrastructure at least annually?
column7: Annually recurring checklist, and calendar event
column8: OpenVAS (install linux distro) and Nessus (16 free hosts, can do web application testing)

column4: Do you conduct application penetration tests of your cloud infrastructure regularly as prescribed by industry best practices and guidance?
column8: OpenVAS (install linux distro) and Nessus (16 free hosts, can do web application testing)

column4: Do you have a program in place that includes the ability to monitor changes to the regulatory requirements in relevant jurisdictions, adjust your security program for changes to legal requirements, and ensure compliance with relevant regulatory requirements?
column6: We seek to maintain compliance to the cyber security laws of our target markets. Being based in Australia, we ensure that our operation is in compliance with Australian laws.

column4: Are business continuity plans subject to testing at planned intervals or upon significant organizational or environmental changes to ensure continuing effectiveness?
column6: Various testing is performed (which includes stress testing and functional testing) regularly.

column4: Are policies and procedures established and made available for all personnel to adequately support services operations’ roles?
column6: Onboarding and best practice documentation

column4: Do you have technical capabilities to enforce tenant data retention policies?
column6: Our offering does not include multi-tenancy. Having said that, all data sits in our DB so we have full control over our user data.

column4: Have you implemented backup or recovery mechanisms to ensure compliance with regulatory, statutory, contractual or business requirements?
column6: Regular backup and additional backups prior to major operations, such as server upgrades

column4: Do you test your backup or redundancy mechanisms at least annually?
column6: Databases are restored using backup snapshots to ensure the redundancy mechanism is working.
column7: Annually recurring checklist, and calendar event

column4: Do you have controls in place to restrict and monitor the installation of unauthorized software onto your systems?
column6: This is achieved by leveraging threat detection services that provide protection against malwarein our systems.

column4: Do you provide standardized (e.g. ISO/IEC) non-proprietary encryption algorithms (3DES, AES, etc.) to tenants in order for them to protect their data if it is required to move through public networks (e.g., the Internet)?
column6: All data transfers are conducted over Transport Layer Security (TLS) 1.2+.

column4: Do you utilize open encryption methodologies any time your infrastructure components need to communicate with each other via public networks (e.g., Internet-based replication of data from one environment to another)?
column6: Client-server communication is conducted over HTTPS

column4: Do you have procedures in place to ensure production data shall not be replicated or used in non-production environments?
column6: Our operating procedure and tooling do not support copying and distribution of production data outside of our production environment. Copying of production data is only performed in the form of encrypted offline snapshots for backup purposes and in this case, the snapshots are not downloadable and stay within our cloud infrastructure.

column4: Do you support the secure deletion (e.g., degaussing/cryptographic wiping) of archived and backed-up data?
column6: Hardware level deletion of data is handled by our Cloud provider, AWS.

column4: Can you provide a published procedure for exiting the service arrangement, including assurance to sanitize all computing resources of tenant data once a customer has exited your environment or has vacated a resource?
column6: Our offering does not include multi-tenancy. Having said that, all user and organization data will be deleted after a certain period once they have chosen to delete their accounts.
column7: TODO: Link to privacy policy on deletion

column4: Do you maintain a complete inventory of all of your critical assets located at all sites/ or geographical locations and their assigned ownership?
column6: We maintain a list of all the assets that required for the functioning of our Web application and business operations.

column4: Are physical security perimeters (e.g., fences, walls, barriers, guards, gates, electronic surveillance, physical authentication mechanisms, reception desks, and security patrols) implemented for all areas housing sensitive data and information systems?
column6: Data storage is managed by AWS. TODO: Read AWS policy

column4: Do you restrict physical access to information assets and functions by users and support personnel?
column6: Our personnel has limited access to production data based on the intended role that they need to carry out. Our engineers has access only to high level production data for debugging purposes, but they do NOT have access to personal data and uploaded documents.

column4: Do you have a capability to allow creation of unique encryption keys per tenant?
column6: Our offering does not include multi-tenancy.

column4: Do you encrypt tenant data at rest (on disk/storage) within your environment?
column6: Our offering does not include multi-tenancy. Having said that, database level encryption is managed by our Cloud Service Provider, AWS, Additionally, we implemented application level encryption for sensitive data to ensure that the data is not readable even in the event of direct unauthorized access to the database.

column4: Do you have documented information security baselines for every component of your infrastructure (e.g., hypervisors, operating systems, routers, DNS servers, etc.)?

Are your information security policies and procedures made available to all impacted personnel and business partners, authorized by accountable business role/function and supported by the information security management program as per industry best practices (e.g. ISO 27001, SOC 2)?
column6: Our security policy can be found on our website.

column4: Is a formal disciplinary or sanction policy established for employees who have violated security policies and procedures?
column7: TODO: Write security policy that tells users how we and our employees treat their data

column4: Do you notify your tenants when you make material changes to your information security and/or privacy policies?
column6: Our latest security and privacy policies can be accessed directly from our website.

column4: Do you perform, at minimum, annual reviews to your privacy and security policies?
column6: We track a list of items that need to be reviewed annually, which includes privacy and security policies.

column4: Upon termination of contract or business relationship, are employees and business partners adequately informed of their obligations for returning organizationally-owned assets?
column6: Organization assets that are lent to employees or business partners will need to be returned.  This is generally made clear at the beginning.

column4: Pursuant to local laws, regulations, ethics, and contractual constraints, are all employment candidates, contractors, and involved third parties subject to background verification?
column6: Background verification is only required for employees who have important roles and have wider access to our systems and data.

column4: Do your employment agreements incorporate provisions and/or terms in adherence to established information governance and security policies?
column6: TODO: need the document (employment contract)

column4: Are documented policies, procedures, and guidelines in place to govern change in employment and/or termination?
column6: TODO: need the document for termination checklist

column4: Are personnel trained and provided with awareness programs at least once a year?
column6: Although there is not a formal program on this, awareness on cyber security and user privacy are communicated regularly to the employees in meetings.

column4: Do you restrict, log, and monitor access to your information security management systems (e.g., hypervisors, firewalls, vulnerability scanners, network sniffers, APIs, etc.)?
column6: We employ various security tools for monitoring and analyzing the security of our systems.

column4: Do you monitor and log privileged access (e.g., administrator level) to information security management systems?
column6: We monitor and log access to important data and administrative management area instead.
column7: TODO: why do we need to monitor the systems?

column4: Do you have controls in place ensuring timely removal of systems access that is no longer required for business purposes?
column6: TODO: termination checklist needed

column4: Do you manage and store the identity of all personnel who have access to the IT infrastructure, including their level of access?
column6: Only the highest level of our technical personnel has access to the IT infrastructure.

column4: Are controls in place to prevent unauthorized access to your application, program, or object source code, and assure it is restricted to authorized personnel only?
column6: Access is only given to personnel based on the roles they need to perform. No access is given out unnecessarily.

column4: Are controls in place to prevent unauthorized access to tenant application, program, or object source code, and assure it is restricted to authorized personnel only?
column6: Our offering does not include separate environments for tenants.

column4: Do you document how you grant, approve and enforce access restrictions to tenant/customer credentials following the rules of least privilege?
column6: Access to tenant/customer credentials is simply not possible as user provided passwords are hashed using one-way hashing algorithm.

column4: Do you require a periodical authorization and validation (e.g. at least annually) of the entitlements for all system users and administrators (exclusive of users maintained by your tenants), based on the rule of least privilege, by business leadership or other accountable business role or function?
column6: This is included in the list of items that we review annually.

column4: Is timely deprovisioning, revocation, or modification of user access to the organizations systems, information assets, and data implemented upon any change in status of employees, contractors, customers, business partners, or involved third parties?
column6: For the average personnel, access to all important assets and data can be disabled through the deactivation of a single account.

column4: Are file integrity (host) and network intrusion detection (IDS) tools implemented to help facilitate timely detection, investigation by root cause analysis, and response to incidents?
column6: TODO

column4: Is physical and logical user access to audit logs restricted to authorized personnel?
Are audit logs reviewed on a regular basis for security events (e.g., with automated tools)?
Do you use a synchronized time-service protocol (e.g., NTP) to ensure all systems have a common time reference?
column6: This is handled by our could service provider.

column4: Are operating systems hardened to provide only the necessary ports, protocols, and services to meet business needs using technical controls (e.g., antivirus, file integrity monitoring, and logging) as part of their baseline build standard or template?
For your SaaS or PaaS offering, do you provide tenants with separate environments for production and test processes?
column6: Our service is not multi-tenant.

column4: Do you logically and physically segregate production and non-production environments?
column6: These environments are set up in separate Cloud server clusters.

column4: Are system and network environments protected by a firewall or virtual firewall to ensure business and customer security requirements?
column6: This protective firewall layer is implemented using Cloudflare.

column4: Do you restrict personnel access to all hypervisor management functions or administrative consoles for systems hosting virtualized systems based on the principle of least privilege and supported through technical controls (e.g., two-factor authentication, audit trails, IP address filtering, firewalls and TLS-encapsulated communications to the administrative consoles)?
column6: This is achieved by employing role-based administrative console access that is equipped with audit trail and 2FA enforcement.

column4: Are policies and procedures established and mechanisms configured and implemented to protect the wireless network environment perimeter and to restrict unauthorized wireless traffic?
column6: Our servers are hosted on the cloud and any interaction that we have with the could is encrypted using TLS 1.2+.

column4: Are policies and procedures established and mechanisms implemented to ensure wireless security settings are enabled with strong encryption for authentication and transmission, replacing vendor default settings (e.g., encryption keys, passwords, SNMP community strings)?
column6: Our servers are hosted on the cloud and any interaction that we have with the could is encrypted using TLS 1.2+.

column4: Are policies and procedures established and mechanisms implemented to protect wireless network environments and detect the presence of unauthorized (rogue) network devices for a timely disconnect from the network?
column6: Our servers are hosted on the cloud and any interaction that we have with the could is encrypted using TLS 1.2+.

column4: Do you publish a list of all APIs available in the service and indicate which are standard and which are customized?
column6: We do not offer any public API.

column4: Do you have a policy enforcement capability (e.g., XACML) to ensure that only approved applications and those from approved application stores can be loaded onto a mobile device?
column6: Our employees and contractors are not provided with mobile devices

column1: Security Incident Management, E-Discovery, & Cloud Forensics
column4: Do you have a documented security incident response plan?
column6: TODO: DB recovery plan

column4: Have you tested your security incident response plans in the last year?
column6: TODO: Try DB recovery

column4: Are workforce personnel and external business relationships adequately informed of their responsibility, and, if required, consent and/or contractually required to report all information security events in a timely manner?
column6: TODO: best practices and employment contract

column4: Do you have predefined communication channels for workforce personnel and external business partners to report incidents in a timely manner adhering to applicable legal, statutory, or regulatory compliance obligations?
column6: Personnel and business partners have dedicated communication channels to report any issues.

column4: Do you enforce and attest to tenant data separation when producing data in response to legal subpoenas?
column6: We will not divulge any data that is not the subject of the legal subpoenas.

column1: Supply Chain Management, Transparency, and Accountability
column4: Do you make security incident information available to all affected customers and providers periodically through electronic methods (e.g., portals)?
column6: Customers are free to contact us on designated communication channels regarding issues that they are facing.

column4: Do you collect capacity and use data for all relevant components of your cloud service offering?
column6: This capability is not relevant to your offering.

column4: Do third-party agreements include provision for the security and protection of information and assets?
column6: We do not distribute non-anonymized data to third parties.

column4: Do you have the capability to recover data for a specific customer in the case of a failure or data loss?
column6: This is highly dependent on the recentness of the data loss occurrence. It gets harder as time goes. In addition, the completeness of the data recovered varied based on conditions.

column4: Do you provide tenants with ongoing visibility and reporting of your operational Service Level Agreement (SLA) performance?
column6: Our offering does not include multi-tenancy.

column4: Do you mandate annual information security reviews and audits of your third party providers to ensure that all agreed upon security requirements are met?
Do you have anti-malware programs that support or connect to your cloud service offerings installed on all of your IT infrastructure network and systems components?
column6: This is achieved using Amazon GuardDuty Malware Protection.

column4: Do you have a capability to patch vulnerabilities across all of your computing devices, applications, and systems?
column6: We use containerization technology to that serves as an intermediary layer between our application code and the underlying operating systems, which means that any updates that are applied to the containers will automatically apply to all machines that run the application code.

column4: Is mobile code authorized before its installation and use, and the code configuration checked, to ensure that the authorized mobile code operates according to a clearly defined security policy?
